etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘slight depression running down the middle of the chest’, surviving as a Scots term): from Old French esclot, of obscure origin

definitions: a long, narrow aperture or slit in a machine for something to be inserted

examples.text: he slid a coin into the slot of the jukebox

shortDefinitions: long, narrow aperture or slit in machine for something

definitions: a groove or channel into which something fits or in which something works, such as one in the head of a screw

examples.text: a screwdriver fitted into the slot

shortDefinitions: groove or channel into which something fits or in which something works, such as one in head of screw

definitions: an allotted place in an arrangement or plan such as a broadcasting schedule
shortDefinitions: allotted place in arrangement or scheme such as broadcasting schedule

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

definitions: place (something) into a long, narrow aperture

examples.text: he slotted a cassette into the tape machine
the plates come in sections that can be slotted together

shortDefinitions: place something into long, narrow aperture

definitions: be placed or able to be placed into a slot

examples.text: the processors will slot into a personal computer

shortDefinitions: be placed or able to be placed into such aperture

etymologies: late 16th century: from Old French esclot ‘hoof print of a horse’, probably from Old Norse slóth ‘trail’; compare with sleuth

definitions: the track of a deer, visible as slotted footprints in soft ground.
shortDefinitions: track of deer, as visible in soft ground
